results.content:
There is no theory or discussion in this course. It is basically just someone running through a bunch of examples with no real discussion of what is happening. If your code differs from the sample code, you have no real idea of how to handle the tests for it.

For example, the entire first 1/4 of the course centers around an example with a service that adds and subtracts numbers. There are no functions that are this simple.

I was hoping for something that explains all the things that need to be tested and a discussion of how to test those. Then, you go through some examples so that a user can see the basics and figure out how to do things on their own. This is just a guy coding with no real helpful information.
results.content_html:

results.content: This was an excellent course. I started doing unit testing at work, and this has helped fill in the gaps I had from reading blogs and stackoverflow articles. The author does a fantastic job explaining the subject matter. He has a non-English accent, but was easy to understand in all but a few cases. I would have loved to see another module on more advanced topics, such as mocking functions with parameters, and how to increase code coverage in the code coverage report. If he makes a follow-on course to this one, I will purchase it eagerly.
results.content_html: This was an excellent course. I started doing unit testing at work, and this has helped fill in the gaps I had from reading blogs and stackoverflow articles. The author does a fantastic job explaining the subject matter. He has a non-English accent, but was easy to understand in all but a few cases. I would have loved to see another module on more advanced topics, such as mocking functions with parameters, and how to increase code coverage in the code coverage report. If he makes a follow-on course to this one, I will purchase it eagerly.

results.content:
Great course but lack of explanation possible problematic things with depricated methods and so one. 
For instance TestBed.get(CoursesService) - method get is depricated.
Also coursesService.findAllCourses.and.returnValue(of(beginnerCourses)) - for me "and" causes error "Property 'and' does not exist on type '() => Observable<Course[]>'"

Anyway except for that, very good tutorial ;)

results.content:
This course is a very good introduction to unit testing. Sure, it is not covering all possible use cases. But I prefer having
a clear and precise understanding on main concepts than a super complete but sloppy knowledge transfer .
Furthermore,  you can always complement with the official Angular docs.

I particularly enjoyed the part about fakeAsync and async test zones. These are thoroughly explained and it helps having a far better understanding than the one given by the official framework documentation.
Maybe one or two additional videos about rxjs marble tests could have been a plus but apart from that, this is a quality course !
results.content_html:
This course is a very good introduction to unit testing. Sure, it is not covering all possible use cases. But I prefer having
a clear and precise understanding on main concepts than a super complete but sloppy knowledge transfer .
Furthermore, you can always complement with the official Angular docs.

I particularly enjoyed the part about fakeAsync and async test zones. These are thoroughly explained and it helps having a far better understanding than the one given by the official framework documentation.
Maybe one or two additional videos about rxjs marble tests could have been a plus but apart from that, this is a quality course !

results.content: Yes. Generally very clearly explained and the course materials are well laid out. Occasionally there are a few sentences that can be a terminology traffic jam, but I understand this is very hard to avoid in Web Development!
results.content_html: Yes. Generally very clearly explained and the course materials are well laid out. Occasionally there are a few sentences that can be a terminology traffic jam, but I understand this is very hard to avoid in Web Development!

results.content: Vasco, you are a very good teacher, and you can explain the Big Picture very well. I appreciate your embedded instructions, too. Thank you and keep on teaching us.
results.content_html: Vasco, you are a very good teacher, and you can explain the Big Picture very well. I appreciate your embedded instructions, too. Thank you and keep on teaching us.

results.content:
The course gave a good introduction into unit testing and a quick glimpse into E2E Testing. 
I think I now have a good understanding the basics of unit testing, and I can test most of what I want to test. 

However, there are some things I consider crucial, which were not covered. 
Performance optimisation of the tests is not really covered. Component testing could be more detailed in my opinion, especially when it is useful to test the HTML, as these tests are often expensive (at least in my project). 

That being said, the course was well structured and presented, thank you Vasco for the great content! This is not my first course from Angular University and it won't be the last.
results.content_html:
The course gave a good introduction into unit testing and a quick glimpse into E2E Testing.

Performance optimisation of the tests is not really covered. Component testing could be more detailed in my opinion, especially when it is useful to test the HTML, as these tests are often expensive (at least in my project).

That being said, the course was well structured and presented, thank you Vasco for the great content! This is not my first course from Angular University and it won't be the last.

results.content: It have the essentials to understand how to make unit testing in angular, and also, e2e test. Is well explained and is easy to understand. A pretty good Course overall.
results.content_html: It have the essentials to understand how to make unit testing in angular, and also, e2e test. Is well explained and is easy to understand. A pretty good Course overall.

results.content:
The lectures are really awesome, explained very well.

Things that need to cover.
1. BehaviourSubject in this module when other component wants to subscribe.
2. When you click on the Edit button, the component gets open, this behavior test case should have covered.
3. You Should have provided with some tools where after completion of CI success, Deployment can happen to the free hosting website and we can access our application.
4.  Integration of SonarQube with the angular application.

results.content: It is the first time that I start and finish a course from Angular University, and the experience has been positive. I've learned a lot about Unit Testing in Angular. The examples are very clear and his explanations are as well. If your main objective is to start doing Unit Testing in Angular, there are no doubts that this is your course.
results.content_html: It is the first time that I start and finish a course from Angular University, and the experience has been positive. I've learned a lot about Unit Testing in Angular. The examples are very clear and his explanations are as well. If your main objective is to start doing Unit Testing in Angular, there are no doubts that this is your course.

results.content:
I love Vasco's teaching style. His courses are the best I've seen on Udemy. I recommend him to my colleagues at work. 

This Angular testing course gave me the foundation to help me with unit testing Angular apps. I have a much better understanding on the confusing aspects of asynchronous and component testing. The section on code coverage was a huge bonus.

Although not relevant to me I was pleased to see and play with Cypress in this course. Was surprised that Protractor was not even mentioned.

I would have loved to see how to integrate the Karma unit tests with a Continuous Integration pipeline.

One feedback for improvement would be to avoid using the "any" data type in code samples and instead prefer the static typing provided by TypeScript. Examples of this include the section on creating Spy Objects. It is a very bad habit Angular developers find hard to break when they resort to typing anything they don't understand with "any".
results.content_html:
I love Vasco's teaching style. His courses are the best I've seen on Udemy. I recommend him to my colleagues at work.

This Angular testing course gave me the foundation to help me with unit testing Angular apps. I have a much better understanding on the confusing aspects of asynchronous and component testing. The section on code coverage was a huge bonus.

Although not relevant to me I was pleased to see and play with Cypress in this course. Was surprised that Protractor was not even mentioned.

I would have loved to see how to integrate the Karma unit tests with a Continuous Integration pipeline.

One feedback for improvement would be to avoid using the "any" data type in code samples and instead prefer the static typing provided by TypeScript. Examples of this include the section on creating Spy Objects. It is a very bad habit Angular developers find hard to break when they resort to typing anything they don't understand with "any".

results.content: As expected, the course was very detailed, but clearly presented. The practical approach makes it easy to develop an understanding for good case scenarios. I am very happy with the course and can definitely recommend it to others.
results.content_html: As expected, the course was very detailed, but clearly presented. The practical approach makes it easy to develop an understanding for good case scenarios. I am very happy with the course and can definitely recommend it to others.

results.content:
Very intuitive and detailed course.  It has provided a strong foundation to continue building my knowledge on.

The only reason I have not given 5 stars is due to the fairly poor quality of the captions.  Due to my hearing problems, I rely on the captions but there were too many spelling mistakes, missed words, etc hindering the learning process.

I still recommend the course.

If possible let me know which testing framework is best for unit testing and e2e testing in angular.

results.content: I had high expectations considering the build up of the same over a month. I am currently in a project that requires Testing and was desperately looking for references.  I would say, this course is a good introduction, definitely not a masterclass or a complete guide.  Testing of directives / pipes / things like @ViewChild / life cycle hooks , guards, marble testing etc has not been covered at all. I felt a bit half-baked mid way through to be honest. If you ask me, I got an overview, but definitely not in depth.

results.content: This was a good testing course that covered a lot of ground in a short time. Particular attention was placed on managing the asynchronous nature of Angular.
results.content_html: This was a good testing course that covered a lot of ground in a short time. Particular attention was placed on managing the asynchronous nature of Angular.

results.content: Goede cursus, maar wel met onvoldoende diepgang. Wat ik vooral miste was: hergebruik (al dan niet geparametriseerd, met name van belang voor cypress tests), in depth behandeling van cypress commands en testen (zowel cypress als jasmine) van forms (afhandeling en validatie van user input, en dan dus niet alleen een click actie op een knop).
results.content_html: Goede cursus, maar wel met onvoldoende diepgang. Wat ik vooral miste was: hergebruik (al dan niet geparametriseerd, met name van belang voor cypress tests), in depth behandeling van cypress commands en testen (zowel cypress als jasmine) van forms (afhandeling en validatie van user input, en dan dus niet alleen een click actie op een knop).

results.content: I really like this course. The approach for explaining issues step-by-step help me to understand what is going on. Purposely implementing errors in a natural way, to make me as a course follower experience how the tests respond to situations and then fixing the issues. I like it!
results.content_html: I really like this course. The approach for explaining issues step-by-step help me to understand what is going on. Purposely implementing errors in a natural way, to make me as a course follower experience how the tests respond to situations and then fixing the issues. I like it!

results.content:
Excellent explanation of basic Angular Testing. 

Some topics are missing such as testing Directive, Routing, and Forms, especially reactive forms.

Look forward an advanced testing course including TDD.
results.content_html:
Excellent explanation of basic Angular Testing.

Some topics are missing such as testing Directive, Routing, and Forms, especially reactive forms.

Look forward an advanced testing course including TDD.

results.content: I thought the course did an excellent job of explaining angular testing.  But I think an advanced testing course to dive even deeper ... maybe a course strictly on cypress ... how to get past login, etc.  Overall the course did an excellent job.
results.content_html: I thought the course did an excellent job of explaining angular testing. But I think an advanced testing course to dive even deeper ... maybe a course strictly on cypress ... how to get past login, etc. Overall the course did an excellent job.

results.content: This course did a good job in presenting the tools needed to test angular applications, but i feel it was more like an introduction than a masterclass. Would have prefered it if it got more hands on and tested many more components with different purposes and functionalities.
results.content_html: This course did a good job in presenting the tools needed to test angular applications, but i feel it was more like an introduction than a masterclass. Would have prefered it if it got more hands on and tested many more components with different purposes and functionalities.

results.content: Long awaited for a good course on Angular testing. Highly recommended, simple to follow and covers realistic testing scenarios that one may encounter. Thanks for great material.
results.content_html: Long awaited for a good course on Angular testing. Highly recommended, simple to follow and covers realistic testing scenarios that one may encounter. Thanks for great material.

results.content: Great course for learning Jasmine unit testing with Angular. Explains topics such as asynchronous unit tests in a clear and concise way. End to end testing with Cypress section is a bit short, but explains the basics well.
results.content_html: Great course for learning Jasmine unit testing with Angular. Explains topics such as asynchronous unit tests in a clear and concise way. End to end testing with Cypress section is a bit short, but explains the basics well.

results.content: It was a great course, it helped be better understand how tests are written now a days. Lots of stuff is made easier from the my time learning early versions of Selenium. I was hoping to see how material dialogs were tested, but, overall the course expanded my knowledge and helps me develop better code with a testing mindset.

results.content: Good, but much too slow. I think that when someone cares about testing, he or she is probably familiar with concepts such as asynchronosity or basics of Angular testing. Most of the stuff about asynchronous components could be sped up considerably; no one tests with setTimeout (why would you if you have Angular testing tools). One lesson about this would have sufficed.
results.content_html: Good, but much too slow. I think that when someone cares about testing, he or she is probably familiar with concepts such as asynchronosity or basics of Angular testing. Most of the stuff about asynchronous components could be sped up considerably; no one tests with setTimeout (why would you if you have Angular testing tools). One lesson about this would have sufficed.

results.content:
I think it's good course. Maybe you should cover up Protractor as the default angular e2e thing.
Also I would recommend you, to write more clean code - many beginners will watch this ;) 

But: Everything covered up really good and comprehensive, so over all a good job - I now know more then before, thats the goal.

Kind regards from Germany :)

results.content: First, hats off for making a separate course on testing only. Developers tend to emphasize how important testing is, but at the end of the day the amount of resources on testing is ridiculuously scarce. And most blogposts provide code ideas but not how to test them properly. Now, on to the rating: As an intermediate angular user, I can say this course would have been for me a treasure to have a while ago, although I still have some takeaways from it. This is a great primer. I would expect maybe some more material about running rxjs TestScheduler and marble-like testing, about utilizing Jest, snapshots... Big shoutout for noticing that rxjs 'of' is a synchronous thing.
results.content_html: First, hats off for making a separate course on testing only. Developers tend to emphasize how important testing is, but at the end of the day the amount of resources on testing is ridiculuously scarce. And most blogposts provide code ideas but not how to test them properly. Now, on to the rating: As an intermediate angular user, I can say this course would have been for me a treasure to have a while ago, although I still have some takeaways from it. This is a great primer. I would expect maybe some more material about running rxjs TestScheduler and marble-like testing, about utilizing Jest, snapshots... Big shoutout for noticing that rxjs 'of' is a synchronous thing.
